Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 s.raw_text: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 s.proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The opinion in Blixt v. Blixt concerns a grandparent visitation petition brought under Massachusetts General Laws c. 119, § 39D, and the constitutional analysis of that grandparent visitation statute. It does not involve or discuss an action filed under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 or 28A, nor does it address the jurisdiction of the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under those divorce/child support/visitation provisions. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition stated.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff filed a complaint in the Probate and Family Court seeking visitation with the child under G. L. c. 119, § 39D, the so-called grandparent visitation statute (statute)."

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion is an appeal from an amended judgment of divorce and related orders; it is not described as an action filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court, nor does it purport to rest jurisdiction on G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 28A. The only direct reference to § 28 is near the end regarding modification of custody, and § 28A is not mentioned at all. Thus, this case does not support the specific jurisdictional proposition stated.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father.”

Prenaveau v. Preville, 409 Mass. 141 (19.proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Prenaveau v. Preville, 409 Mass. 141 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is an appeal in an eviction/summary process matter from the Housing Court concerning a Section 8 tenancy and application of § 504 of the Federal Rehabilitation Act. It does not involve the Bristol County Probate and Family Court, nor does it mention or rely on Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, §§ 28 or 28A (which concern divorce-related matters such as child support and custody). Therefore, it does not support the claimed proposition about jurisdiction under those statutes.
Prenaveau v. Preville, 409 Mass. 141 (19.relevant_excerpt: This is an eviction proceeding brought by the plaintiff landlord against the defendant tenant whose residential tenancy is subsidized under the Federal Section 8 Moderate Rehabilitation Program administered by the Housing Allowance Project, Inc. (HAP). A judge in the Housing Court granted possession to the tenant and the landlord has appealed. We transferred the appeal here from the Appeals Court on our own initiative, and we now affirm the judgment below.

Grubert v. Grubert, 392 Mass. 46 (1984).proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Grubert v. Grubert, 392 Mass. 46 (1984).support_reasoning: The opinion in Grubert v. Grubert concerns criminal convictions and Fourth Amendment search-and-seizure issues relating to a vehicle identification; it does not involve a Probate and Family Court matter, nor does it mention Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, sections 28 or 28A, or the Bristol County Probate and Family Court. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition that an action was filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under jurisdiction granted by those statutes.
Grubert v. Grubert, 392 Mass. 46 (1984).relevant_excerpt: In the instant case, no physical intrusion of any sort was committed. The victim’s identification of the defendant’s vehicle was accomplished solely by her observation of the automobile’s exterior and certain aspects of its interior which were in plain view through the car’s windows. ... Based on our evaluation of the three factors of the place, the property searched, and the precautions taken, we conclude that no reasonable expectation of privacy was violated... We find no error in the judge’s denial of the defendant’s motion to suppress the victim’s identification testimony.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 103 (2021).proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 103 (2021).support_reasoning: The opinion is a Supreme Judicial Court bar admission case, not a Bristol County Probate and Family Court custody or divorce action. It is decided under G.L. c. 221, § 37 and S.J.C. rules concerning bar admission and reinstatement, not under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 or 28A, which govern divorce-related custody and support jurisdiction. Nothing in the opinion discusses or relies on Chapter 208 or the jurisdiction of the Probate and Family Court, so it does not support the claimed proposition about that court’s authority under those statutes.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 103 (2021).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 221, § 37 (1994 ed.), states in relevant part that ‘[a] citizen of the United States, if over eighteen, may file a petition in the supreme judicial court or superior court to be examined for admission as an attorney at law. Unless the court otherwise orders, the clerk of such court shall refer the petition to the board of bar examiners to ascertain his acquirements and qualifications.’”

DiGloria v. DiGloria, 414 Mass. 399 (201.proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
DiGloria v. DiGloria, 414 Mass. 399 (201.case_name: West Broadway Task Force v. Boston Housing Authority
DiGloria v. DiGloria, 414 Mass. 399 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Boston Housing Authority relocation-assistance case in the Superior Court (transferred to the SJC). It does not involve the Bristol County Probate and Family Court, nor does it mention or rely on Massachusetts General Laws c. 208 §§ 28 or 28A, which govern post-divorce custody/support jurisdiction. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition about jurisdiction under those statutes.
DiGloria v. DiGloria, 414 Mass. 399 (201.relevant_excerpt: This action, a class action for declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of those members of the class subject to relocation due to renovations at the BHA’s West Broadway development, began in the Superior Court Department as part of Armando Perez vs. Boston Hous. Auth., Suffolk Superior Court No. 17222. (See Perez v. Boston Hous. Auth., 379 Mass. 703 [1980].)

Troupe v. Nelson, 469 Mass. 735 (2015).proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Troupe v. Nelson, 469 Mass. 735 (2015).support_reasoning: The opinion provided is not Troupe v. Nelson, 469 Mass. 735 (2015), but a Massachusetts murder case (Commonwealth v. Howard) in the Superior Court. The text concerns criminal procedure, suppression of statements, prior bad acts, prosecutorial argument, and jury instructions; it does not involve the Bristol County Probate and Family Court, nor jurisdiction under G.L. c. 208 §§ 28 and 28A, which govern divorce and related family-law matters. Therefore it cannot support the stated family-court jurisdiction proposition.
Troupe v. Nelson, 469 Mass. 735 (2015).relevant_excerpt: [No portion of the provided opinion discusses the Bristol County Probate and Family Court or jurisdiction under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 or 28A. The case instead concerns a murder conviction, suppression issues, prior bad acts, and jury instructions in a criminal proceeding. No relevant excerpt is available. ]

Custody of Drury, 395 Mass. 688 (2016).proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Custody of Drury, 395 Mass. 688 (2016).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a taxpayer appeal from a decision of the Appellate Tax Board regarding timeliness under Massachusetts tax statutes (G.L. c. 62C, § 39 and G.L. c. 58A, § 10). It does not involve a custody action, the Bristol County Probate and Family Court, or jurisdiction under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 or 28A. Therefore, it does not support the proposition about jurisdiction for a custody action in the Probate and Family Court.
Custody of Drury, 395 Mass. 688 (2016).relevant_excerpt:
The board, after a hearing on the jurisdictional issue, allowed the Commissioner’s motion to dismiss, finding that the taxpayers’ appeal was not filed “within sixty days after the date of notice of the decision of the commissioner.” G. L. c. 62C, § 39 (1984 ed.).
...
Because the taxpayers failed to make a timely request for a stenographic record, they are “deemed to have waived all rights of appeal ... as to whether a finding was warranted by the evidence.” G. L. c. 58A, § 10 (1984 ed.).

Conti v. Conti, 466 Mass. 381 (2013).proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Conti v. Conti, 466 Mass. 381 (2013).case_name: Soe v. Sex Offender Registry Board
Conti v. Conti, 466 Mass. 381 (2013).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns judicial review of a Sex Offender Registry Board classification and discusses jurisdiction under G.L. c. 6 and c. 30A, not actions under G.L. c. 208 §§ 28 and 28A (which involve divorce and post‑divorce matters in Probate and Family Court). There is no mention of Bristol County Probate and Family Court, Chapter 208, or sections 28 or 28A, so this case does not provide authority for that jurisdictional proposition.
Conti v. Conti, 466 Mass. 381 (2013).relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff sought review of his final classification in Superior Court pursuant to G. L. c. 6, § 178M, and a judge in the Superior Court affirmed the board’s decision. The plaintiff appealed, and we transferred his appeal to this court on our own motion.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: This action is filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under the jurisdiction granted by Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208 sections 28 and 28A.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court decision reviewing divorce, custody, removal, alimony, and property division orders, but it does not state that the action was filed in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court or that jurisdiction was based on G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 28A. The opinion mentions other statutes (e.g., c. 208, §§ 1B, 30, 31; c. 215, § 56A) but never references §§ 28 or 28A or identifies the specific county probate and family court. Therefore, it does not support the precise jurisdictional proposition claimed.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: On October 16, 1984, substantively identical judgments were entered granting a divorce nisi in the cross actions for divorce on the ground of the irretrievable breakdown of the marriage (G. L. c. 208, § 1B [1984 ed.]). ... The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not ... be removed out of this commonwealth ... unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.”
